He also said that Boeing engineers made bad mistakes in the implementation of the MCAS system, and in which he also said that he would let his family fly, as you just noted. It's an important reminder that, even at its peak usage, there were 8,600 MAX flights every week across the world. That boils down to about 1,978,000 passengers who flew without incident on MAX 8 planes every week. Your chances of being in a MAX 8 crash were roughly the same as your chances of winning the Mega Millions lottery. All of that said, once the plane is recertified, Charles, Boeing is going to face an uphill battle in regaining the public's confidence, at least in total -- back to you.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's going to be a tough P.R. act certainly out of the gate. Thanks a lot, Doug. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: MCKELWAY
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: And to more trouble in the skies, a man suing Delta and one of its passengers after an emotional support dog allegedly attacked him on a flight in 2017. So, does he have a case? Let's ask our legal guests, attorneys Natalie Elisha Gold and Janell Weinstein. Janell, let me start with you. It's kind of frightening to think that an emotional support dog might have attacked someone unprovoked. But where does it stand legally?

utterances.speaker: JANELL WEINSTEIN, ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: Well, it's a tough case for the airlines. But at the end of the day, as a practical matter, the case is going to settle. There's a bigger issue here, which is really the regulations that are in place to protect passengers and the airlines. The airlines acknowledge that there's a problem. The question in this case is, what...

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: They acknowledge there is a problem with the...

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: There is a problem with these emotional support dogs and the regulations. The question in this case is whether or not the airline was negligent. And there's no indication at this point that they were aware that this particular animal was a danger.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: So, Natalie, walk us through how this all went down.

utterances.speaker: NATALIE ELISHA GOLD, ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: So there was a very large dog in the middle aisle. And as the man gone onto his window seat, he was mauled and attacked by this huge dog. And then the dog was stopped. And the dog then came back and started biting his face to the point of 28 stitches. If you think that's not negligent, what is?

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: And the question is, who's -- and who is responsible for the negligence, right? Certainly, the owner who had this dog on his lap and did not make...

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Well, it's a large dog, and it was on the owner's lap?

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: That's correct, on the owner's lap. It was actually a 50-pound dog. The problem here...

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: That's a big dog.

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: Yes, Charles, the problem is the regulations. The Department of Transportation has regulations that accommodate service animals, which include these emotional support dogs.

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: However, it is up to the discretion of all these different airlines to implement certain rules.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right, because we have seen where some are saying, hey, this is an emotional support animal. Some will take a peacock. Some will take whatever. But they do have discretion there. And they have been exercising it.

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: Only to a certain extent. They don't have the -- they don't have the right to refuse an animal to come on, an emotional support animal, if some passenger is uncomfortable, or if the crew is uncomfortable, if there isn't any risk to their safety.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: What about the certification process for these animals? Who does that? And are they liable?

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's completely bogus. I mean, I looked up on my way here, can I certify my animal for an emotional support certification? Yes. For $79.99, so can you. And people are getting away with this. And they're taking free flights with their pets, and, quite frankly, to the detriment of the other people on the flight. And it's not OK.

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: And that's why Congress has come in. They passed -- they are making the DOT, the Department of Transportation, look at this very carefully. And they're looking out for comments. What the airlines want, and are asking the Department of Transportation to do, is to put the regulations in line what the Department of Justice has, which is, the Department of Justice is not required to accommodate emotional support animals. You don't see them on buses and trains. You don't see them in stadiums. That's what the airlines would like as well, because the problem is, those people that have a disability...

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: ...with a service animal that is trained and is able to behave properly in those environments, that's what you want on a plane.

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: And they're really losing it, because the thing is, the people who really need it, the deaf person who needs an animal to help them, is now -- they're -- the people are just taking advantage.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: So, the system is being abused?

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. And it's really disgraceful.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: When it's all said and done, do you agree with Janell that there will be some sort of settlement? And -- but the bottom line is, this passenger who was mauled, he will get a financial -- some kind of a financial settlement?

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: I -- if I was advising Delta, I would say, pay as much as possible, keep it discreet, and make sure that you have the guidelines in place so that this doesn't happen again.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: All right, ladies, thank you both very, very much.

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WEINSTEIN
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Charles.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Appreciate it. Hey, remember those oil pipeline and tanker attacks in the Middle East? Something tells me these guys do. An emergency summit in Saudi Arabia under way right now, it's meant to be a message for Iran. We will meet the military colonel who's worried what it means for us.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: President Trump running a little behind schedule this afternoon, after giving the commencement address at the Air Force Academy in Colorado. And here's why. He shook hands with everyone in the graduating class. We're talking 1,000 cadets. We're back, 60 seconds.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: A coordinated campaign to attack the U.S., a top general spelling out exactly what Iran had planned for us. To our Trace Gallagher with more -- Trace.

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Charles, in his most detailed public remarks yet, General Joseph Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs, said that threats from Iran are nothing new. What is new, he says, is the U.S. intelligence is showing concerning signs on two fronts, first, that Iran was questioning both the will and the capability of the U.S. to respond, and, second, that Iran was conducting a much more coordinated effort. Watch.

utterances.speaker: GEN. JOSEPH DUNFORD, JOINT CHIEFS OF STAFF CHAIRMAN
utterances.utterance: We saw something that looked more like a campaign than individual threat. And it was the geographic span and the -- and the perception that that activity would be tried to be synchronized in time that caused us to look at that threat differently than 40 years, by the way, of malign activity by the Iranians.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.utterance: And, of course, that prompted the U.S. to send an aircraft carrier strike force and a bomber task force to the Middle East. But, today, President Trump tried to take the tension with Iran down a notch, saying he doesn't want military escalation and would be willing to talk. Listen.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I want to get along with everybody if it's possible. I even want to get along with Iran. And Iran wants to talk. And if they want to talk, I'm available.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.utterance: And, initially, an emergency summit convened today in Saudi Arabia was thought to be aimed at cooling tensions in the region. That was until Saudi Arabia's foreign minister urged other Muslim nations to confront Iran over its recent attacks on oil tankers and pipelines in the Persian Gulf. And, finally, Charles, we should note that, today, National Security Adviser John Bolton said there is no doubt Iran attacked those tankers and still wants nuclear weapons -- Charles.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Trace, thank you very much. So, with the Saudis asking the U.S. to be prepared with all options to face the threat from Iran, can we trust them? Retired Lieutenant Colonel Bob Maginnis joins us now. Colonel, thanks for joining us.

utterances.speaker: LT. COL. BOB MAGINNIS (RET.), U.S. ARMY
utterances.utterance: Hey, Charles.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: It's certainly a quagmire, at the very least. We have shown strength here recently. We have sided with the Saudis. But are we on a different page? Do you think they are seeking a military confrontation that we should avoid?

utterances.speaker: MAGINNIS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think we should avoid it, if we can. The Saudis would like us to be in the middle, Charles. They have always wanted us to do the fighting for them. That's why we have hundreds of personnel that are supporting them logistically and training them in- country. And they're a good customer that we -- they have bought hundreds of billions of dollars over the decades from us. The fact is that the president, President Trump, is correct that President Rouhani has indicated he wants to talk. But the problem is, is that the supreme leader, Khamenei, indicates that he doesn't want to talk, he doesn't trust the Americans. So you have got mixed messages from them. But, obviously from us, because John Bolton has, I think, been very pragmatic and very forthright, yes, the Iranians are likely behind the minds and the drones and the threats that we're seeing.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAGINNIS
utterances.utterance: And what General Dunford said, I think, is most concerning, in that there appears to be a campaign -- and he doesn't say that lightly -- with coordinated, widespread activities, having alerted militia and the like around the region. So we do need to pay attention to what the chairman is saying.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Now, there are lots of reports that the economic sanctions are really beginning to bite. By the same token, though, their use of proxy terror in the region has not really abated. In fact, you can argue it's gotten worse in recent weeks. So how do we reconcile those two things? Does it mean that the more their economy crumbles, the more desperate they will become, the more havoc they can wreak in the region? And, if so, what does that mean for us militarily?

utterances.speaker: MAGINNIS
utterances.utterance: No, I think that they will become more desperate. The regime doesn't want to face a Green Revolution, like they did in 2009. It was a bloody mess in Tehran. Yes, the Houthis in Yemen will continue to fire rockets at Riyadh. The Hezbollah will become more active. Hamas will become more active. And, of course, the IRGC, which is already in Syria and Iraq, will continue to target us, much like they did, it looks, two weeks ago there in the Green Zone against our embassy. So, Iran will become more erratic. We just saw the Chinese, interestingly, are going to allow one of their own freighters to come in with Iranian oil. Unfortunately, Beijing's not helping us. And, obviously, neither is Russia.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAGINNIS
utterances.utterance: So their back has been stiffened to a certain degree. Now, they're willing to take it, I think, long-term, because they know and they question our will to stick to it.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Well, and I just read where -- in the Moscow media, where Russia says they will back Iran. But these oil tankers that are at the center of the most recent controversy, do you think that Iran was responsible for the attack on those?

utterances.speaker: MAGINNIS
utterances.utterance: Well, I can only go with what John Bolton has said. If he said -- he obviously has a lot of resources that he's reading into it. The Iranians have a lot of mines. They could close the Strait of Hormuz if they wanted to. We know that. They couldn't keep it closed for a long period of time. It would be a bloody mess. But the reality is, they have been practicing that with small fast boats for a long time. We know their technologies. They are very capable.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Colonel, thank you very much. Really, really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: MAGINNIS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: And new worries from China that you're not hearing about. FOX has new details on the impact China might have on your medicine cabinet and maybe your safety.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: The growing threat from China that you're not hearing about. New details emerging that the U.S. has become dependent on China for medicine. And experts warn, that's a national security threat. FOX News correspondent Bryan Llenas has more -- Bryan.

utterances.speaker: BRYAN LLENAS, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Hey, Charles. Well, look, over the last 20 years, the pursuit of more affordable prescription drugs has now left America too dependent on China for our meds. That's what experts are warning. Our painkillers, antibiotics, vitamins, even aspirin can mostly be sourced to a country the Department of Defense recognizes as an adversary. Now, according to Food and Drug Administration estimates, at least 80 percent of the active ingredients found in all of America's medicines come from abroad, primarily China. And it's not just the ingredients. China wants to become the world's dominant generic drugmaker. Ninety percent of America's prescriptions are for generic versions. So far, Chinese companies are manufacturing generics for everything from high blood pressure meds to cancer drugs. Now, the author of "China Rx," Rosemary Gibson, says this is all part of China's plan. ROSEMARY GIBSON, AUTHOR, "CHINA RX": In five to 10 years, when China has a complete choke hold over the United States and its supply of medicine, it's going to be telling us how much to pay for our medicine. We will lose control over how much we pay. We will be the price taker, not the price setter. And that's devastating.

utterances.speaker: LLENAS
utterances.utterance: Escalating the trade war, China is now threatening to weaponize rare earth minerals. So what happens in a worst-case scenario if China wants to cut the supply for our medicines or alter its quality? Another threat? Medicines used on our troops and veterans can also be sourced to China. And providers may not even know it, because pharmaceutical manufacturers are not required to disclose where they get their ingredients. Now, in a statement to Fox News, Democratic Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio says this -- quote -- "American consumers have a right to know where their ingredients and their medications are coming from, regardless of whether they are brand or generic." Charles, the U.S. Commission on China is holding a hearing on this very threat on July 31.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Bryan, thank you very much. Very disturbing stuff. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: LLENAS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Hey, some Bernie Sanders supporters fearing the DNC is out to burn them again. This time, they claim it's favoring Joe Biden. Where's this going? Well, to the reporter they spoke to -- next.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: The Democratic primaries are still six months away, but, according to The Washington Times, some Bernie Sanders supporters are already fearing the DNC could be backing Joe Biden over their candidate. Washington Times reporter S.A. Miller joins me now. We have reached out to the DNC for a statement, and we are waiting for a response. S.A., what exactly are they seeing to make them -- for them to make this accusation?

utterances.speaker: S.A. MILLER, THE WASHINGTON TIMES
utterances.utterance: Well, they see Biden coming in and immediately dominating the race. And they see what -- I talked to a lot of these activists across the country, and they see kind of a link between the Democratic Party and the mainstream media, which they see as one in the same. They think the polls are rigged. They think they're pushing Biden and giving him much more coverage and kind of promoting him as the inevitable candidate.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: I mean, there's an interesting relationship, right? If you're leading in the polls, you get most of the coverage. And if you get most of the coverage, you might be leading in the polls. But Bernie Sanders certainly seemed like he had a big wind in his sails. And as soon as Biden announced, it was it. That was it. I hardly ever see or hear about him anymore.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.utterance: You sound just like his supporters, who feel the same way. They're -- they're looking for more coverage and him to get his fair shake there. And they're very leery of a lot of these polls. I'm not exactly sure why, but they seem to think that they're not reflective of what's really going on.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: The DNC did make some changes since the last election, I think, with some of the superdelegates and things like that. Can you go through some of the perhaps safeguards that they might have put in place to ensure that this is a little bit fairer? Because it really is hard to argue that Hillary Clinton had a major advantage with her relationship with the DNC over Biden -- I mean, over Sanders last time.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.utterance: That's right. I mean, the DNC has all -- has pretty much admitted that they were trying to sabotage Sanders in 2016 to help Hillary. This -- and to his credit, DNC Chairman Tom Perez came in and took a lot of steps, went out of his way to try and build unity. And that was his number one job when he got there. They adopted new rules for the balloting. The super delegates are not voting in the first ballot at that convention. They opened up the debates now with a criteria to kind of encourage a lot of grassroots involvement and fund-raising to qualify with a pretty low bar. You already got almost 20 people qualified for the first debate.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.utterance: So, they have -- they have done a lot to try and get rid of this impression and put that ugly 2016 primary race behind them.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: What does the Sanders -- what does his supporters say, then, that he's going to have to do? If the DNC is not going to make this a fair race, in his opinion, what will he do? Will he go on the attack? Because, right now, I got to be honest with you. It feels like most of these candidates are running for a second spot on the ticket.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, Sanders, these are his die-hard supporters. These are people who have remained organized since 2016 in kind of a network of grassroots groups out there. And they are confident that, given an opportunity in a free or a fair race, that Sanders will prevail, because they think he's got the winning message.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.utterance: They're looking for him to put away Biden in the debates. They're looking for these types of moves and the groundswell of support actually to carry Bernie there...

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right. Well...

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.utterance: ... provided that the party doesn't somehow get involved and stop that from happening.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right. I mean, Biden -- I mean, Sanders certainly has the most passion, I think, with all these candidates. We will see, though. S.A., thanks a lot. We appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Now, we have heard of Uber banning drivers with low ratings, but riders? Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Uber kicking disrespectful passengers to the curb. The ride-hailing giant unveiling a new policy that would ban riders with low ratings. So, is this fair, and is it smart? Let's ask Internet radio host Mike Gunzelman and Fox News Headlines 24/7 reporter Carley Shimkus. Carley, let me start with you. I don't know that they need to -- I don't know if you guys follow the stock, but it's been an unmitigated disaster. I don't know that they need to be kicking any passengers to the curb.

utterances.speaker: CARLEY SHIMKUS, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: But good news today, right?

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: After the bell, it's up a couple bucks. They got a long way to go, though.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, an Uber executive, in my opinion, put it best when she said, respect is a two-way street. If you think about it, Uber is strange. What's the one thing that every parent would be horrified that their child does? Get in the back of a stranger's car. And that literally is what Uber does.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: So anything to increase safety for passengers and riders is a great idea. But you are right. By kicking passengers out, they are losing business. So this may not be a great business strategy, but they're putting safety first.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Have they said -- laid out exactly all the things that they can give you a low rating for or stop taking you on?

utterances.speaker: MIKE GUNZELMAN, INTERNET RADIO HOST
utterances.utterance: No, that's the thing. So there is -- the problem is, there's no checks and balances. So, for example, that you don't know why you're getting a low rating, especially from a passenger, because obviously the drivers have a rating. If they're loud or obnoxious, you can rate them low. They're like, all right, well, we will do this to the passengers. Now the difference is that if you have below 4.6 rating, which, by the way, I would like a 4.62. And I don't know what I did wrong.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: You're on the cusp. You're on the cusp.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Then you can get banned now from using an Uber.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: No. No, it's not -- they never actually released -- 4.6 is the average for a driver to get potentially kicked off the app. For the passenger, it's interesting, it's actually city by city. So they take the average score.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: So, you can be more obnoxious in New York than...

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: And let's grade by the curve.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Lots of wiggle room in New York.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: And they did release a couple pointers, clean up after yourself, be on time, don't be nasty, all those obvious things.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: The thing is, though, when you are -- say, for example, I get dropped off here, and the Uber driver pulls up and sees a FOX logo. And he might not like FOX. So that -- does that mean I get a low rating? Or perhaps I have a Yankee jersey on and the guy is a Red Sox fan.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: You don't know what's going to happen or what the -- why...

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: I think that the chances of that happening are very slim.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: But it still could happen, though.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: It could happen. There's no -- you don't know exactly why.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but think about the flip side of that. If you have all these passengers that are -- they're disasters, and they're mean, and they could be potentially dangerous to drivers, you don't want them in the back of your car either. So I think Uber is really looking out for their drivers. And on the flip side, they're looking out for the riders as well and have really increased things in terms of safety on that side as well.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: I think what's interesting is that Uber -- and you should stop doing this, by the way -- they're making so many changes. Now they have that silent mode, that you can now -- you have to pay more in order to tell your driver to be silent, which is kind of rude, because they -- to tell them, oh, I don't want to talk to you. I think it should be mandatory that they have air fresheners in every Uber, personally, because that's the problem.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: If I'm Lyft, I'm sitting there thinking OK, tomorrow, I'm going to advertise, bring a boom box. You know what? If your Gunz, you don't have to put on deodorant. We will take you anyway.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: That's -- if you want to know why Uber didn't take you, it doesn't matter. We will take you anyway.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: If I'm Lyft, I'm like, come, talk, have fun. We will get you from point A to point B.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's right. There are other ride-shares too. Like, Via is pretty big in the city. And that's actually a ride-share, so it's not just like a ride-hailing service. And so there are -- there are few reasons really to take the subway anymore, because when you think about the price of Via, it's pretty good.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: But traffic is big, though.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: I mean, driving -- yes, so...

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: My problem with Uber, because I drive in every day, is -- and I'm all for the gig economy. I'm all for people with a side hustle. I think they need a one-day class, because they make traffic. I mean, they stop every five seconds. They're looking at their phone. And when they drop passengers off, they don't pull over. What the heck is going on? One day -- we got one-day training. That's all I'm asking.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: The best part is when they ask me, how do I want to get there? I'm like, no, you're the driver, man. Don't ask me. I'm a passenger. I'm in the back seat.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: No, that's them being courteous.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: I take an Uber every single day to work. And I have a special route.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: Do you really?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: What is your Uber rating?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Gunz, that's low

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: What is yours? What's the range?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Five is the highest. Five is the highest.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: OK, so that's not too bad. That doesn't sound bad.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes. But for anybody to physically rate you low as a passenger, I don't know what I have done on Friday nights. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: I don't know what I have said or drank.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: My Achilles' heel is that I'm always late. And then I'm always so apologetic. Like, oh, don't ruin my rating. I'm so sorry.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: What is your rating?

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Well, 4.74, which I was pretty surprised at. I thought that was low. I promise I'm a nice person.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: You're better than me.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: One of our producers is at 4.86. That's impressive.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: That's good.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: That's gold medal right there.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: That's a polite person.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: I want pointers from them.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: That's a person that bathes and uses deodorant.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: That's really impressive. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: That producer is going places.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: I think they have to grade on a curve system, though. In New York City, you're going to have some pretty rude people. And they're going to be like, yes, my man, get off the phone, turn the music down. You know, take this route, take that route. I think New York is going to be a little bit different than the rest of the country. That's all I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Uber's low rating is probably in the 2's for New York City.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: We're safe.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: I bet you Wyoming -- I bet you Casper, Wyoming has the best average, right? The nicest people in the world. Everyone's at a 5. Thank you both very much.

utterances.speaker: SHIMKUS
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: PAYNE
utterances.utterance: All right, folks, I'm back tomorrow on the FOX Business Network at 2:00 p.m. Eastern time. I will be trying to make you some money in this rough market.
